Dating: LATE PERIOD (not before); GRAECO-ROMAN PERIOD (not after)
Name: Fish
Description: The bronze object, which comes from the excavations of J. Quibell at Elkab, represents a Nile carp or a "lepidotos" This fish is particularly distinguished by a triangular dorsal fin extending the line of the head. The pivot situated in the middle of the ventral part served to insert the object on a socle, which has unfortunately disappeared. The "lepidotos" played an important role in the osirian myth, specifically during the collection of the fragments of the body of Osiris by the goddess Isis. An impure and sethien fish, it was a sacred animal whose cult is spread out over all egyptian territory.
